facts.text: First petitioner has a shop at Mandi Dabwali in Hissar District where he carries on business in the purchase and sale of grains, etc. in wholesale. Customers supply goods loaded in carts drawn by camels or bullocks arriving at godowns at all hours of day and night. Receives messages by telephone and telegram day and night.

Second petitioner carries on retail business on small scale, employs no outsider but attends to work himself with family assistance if necessary. Goods purchased brought at all hours day and night, receives messages during entire period.
Punjab Shops and Commercial Establishments Act, 1958 (Punjab Act 15 of 1958) received assent of President on April 25, 1958, published May 1, 1958, came into force June 1, 1958.
Act applies in first instance to areas in Schedule including Mandi Dabwali.
Section 2(iv) defines commercial establishment as premises wherein business, trade or profession carried on for profit.
Section 7(1): No person employed more than 48 hours/week, 9 hours/day.
Section 9: Establishments open not earlier than 10 AM, close not later than 8 PM, with provisos.
Section 10: Every establishment closed on Sunday, with exceptions.
Section 4 exempts certain establishments from ss.9 and 10, listing clubs, hotels, etc.
Notifications dated June 1, 1958 exempt additional classes and alter hours for others.

legal_issues.text: Whether operative provisions of Punjab Shops and Commercial Establishments Act, 1958, particularly ss.7 and 9, constitute unreasonable restriction on right to carry on trade or business under Art.19(1)(g) protected by Art.19(6).

petitioner_arguments.text: Having regard to nature of petitioners' business requiring 24-hour operation due to arrivals of goods and messages at all hours, impossible to carry on without exemption from restrictions in s.7(1) and s.9.

court_reasoning.text: Regulation of labour conditions for health and efficiency of workers in public interest. Restrictions necessary to avoid overstrain, provide leisure. 48-hour week and opening/closing hours reasonable by modern standards.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Concept of welfare elements dynamic, manifestation of social conscience.

court_reasoning.text: Act contemplates categories: exemptions under s.4, adjustments via provisos to s.9, others conform. Elasticity for particular businesses.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Restrictions in interest of general public, not unreasonable from employer's view.

court_reasoning.text: Concluded against petitioners by Manohar Lal v. State of Punjab upholding weekly close day even for owner-operated shops.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Social interest in worker health; even for owner, public interest; prevents evasion.

holdings.text: Impugned provisions of Act not unreasonable restrictions under Art.19(6).

precedents_cited.case_name: Manohar Lal v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Upheld s.7 Punjab Trade Employees Act 1940 requiring weekly closing even for small trader without employees, on grounds of social interest in health.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition and challenge to restrictions on trade.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Shops and Commercial Establishments Act, 1958
Punjab Trade Employees Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Repealed and re-enacted with modifications; prior upholding relevant.

outcome.summary: Court upheld constitutional validity of ss.7 and 9 of the Act as reasonable regulations in interest of workers' health and public welfare, rejecting petitioners' challenge.

key_quotes.text: The only test of constitutional validity therefore is whether the provision in the impugned law... is unreasonable from the point of view of the employer.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines test for reasonableness under Art.19(6).

key_quotes.text: Judged by this test, neither the 48-hour week, nor the specification of the opening and closing hours can be said to have gone beyond what by modern standards are necessary.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court's conclusion on reasonableness of restrictions.
